elements.content: By introducing an amino substituent group on the dicarboxylate ligand, a porous doubly pillared-layer framework [Co2(abdc)2(bpy)2]·8DMF (2; abdc = 2-amino-1,4-benzene dicarboxylate, bpy = 4,4′-bipyridine) has been obtained, which represents a shape/size modulation of the layer apertures to control over 2-fold interpenetration arising from the nonporous structure of [Co2(bdc)2(bpy)2] (1; bdc = 1,4-benzene dicarboxylate). The bulk-phase purity, framework robustness and permanent porosity of 2 have been confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, and gas adsorption isotherms.
elements.clean_text: By introducing an amino substituent group on the dicarboxylate ligand, a porous doubly pillared-layer framework [Co2(abdc)2(bpy)2]⋅8DMF (2; abdc = 2-amino-1,4-benzene dicarboxylate, bpy = 4,4'-bipyridine) has been obtained, which represents a shape/size modulation of the layer apertures to control over 2-fold interpenetration arising from the nonporous structure of [Co2(bdc)2(bpy)2] (1; bdc = 1,4-benzene dicarboxylate). The bulk-phase purity, framework robustness and permanent porosity of 2 have been confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction, thermogravimetric analysis, and gas adsorption isotherms.

elements.content: Featuring the shape/size control of the layer apertures to avoid 2-fold interpenetration, a porous doubly pillared-layer framework has been obtained, which represents the U-turn from nonporous to porous structure with only adding the amino substituent group on the dicarboxylate ligand.
elements.clean_text: Featuring the shape/size control of the layer apertures to avoid 2-fold interpenetration, a porous doubly pillared-layer framework has been obtained, which represents the U-turn from nonporous to porous structure with only adding the amino substituent group on the dicarboxylate ligand.

elements.content: Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal–organic frameworks (MOFs) are promising porous materials with the advantages of designable frameworks and variable pore sizes/shapes/surface properties for optimizing adsorption performances, as well as other specific applications. Crystal engineering using the periodic networks as blueprints in the design and construction of extended porous frameworks has been proved to be very fruitful, especially in the emerging discipline of reticular chemistry, which targets highly symmetrical networks by linking symmetrical and rigid-shaped multimetallic clusters with organic spacers. Because of the structural fidelity of the building blocks, isoreticular syntheses can therefore be implemented to adjust the pore sizes/shapes by modulating the organic struts. However, interpenetration might inevitably be encountered especially in the self-dual pcu net illustrated by the IRMOF series. Strategies to control over interpenetration of PCPs are therefore important and interesting, but the mystic roles of various synthetic conditions could make the control very tricky and confusing. However, attempts have been devoted to isolate pairs of interpenetrating and noninterpenetrating frameworks by modifying the temperatures, concentrations, metal/linker ratios, additives, etc. Alternatively, the strategy of ligand design can also prevent interpenetration by larger steric hindrances through introducing substituent groups, and a more meticulous route is the utilization of thermal/photo labile groups which can be eliminated by postactivation to preserve the larger free voids. However, the strategy to control over interpenetration by changing the shape of aperture has been scarcely realized until now.
elements.clean_text:
Introduction

Porous coordination polymers (PCPs) or metal-organic frameworks (MOFs) are promising porous materials with the advantages of designable frameworks and variable pore sizes/shapes/surface properties for optimizing adsorption performances, as well as other specific applications. Crystal engineering using the periodic networks as blueprints in the design and construction of extended porous frameworks has been proved to be very fruitful, especially in the emerging discipline of reticular chemistry, which targets highly symmetrical networks by linking symmetrical and rigid-shaped multimetallic clusters with organic spacers. Because of the structural fidelity of the building blocks, isoreticular syntheses can therefore be implemented to adjust the pore sizes/shapes by modulating the organic struts. However, interpenetration might inevitably be encountered especially in the self-dual pcu net illustrated by the IRMOF series. Strategies to control over interpenetration of PCPs are therefore important and interesting, but the mystic roles of various synthetic conditions could make the control very tricky and confusing. However, attempts have been devoted to isolate pairs of interpenetrating and noninterpenetrating frameworks by modifying the temperatures, concentrations, metal/linker ratios, additives, etc. Alternatively, the strategy of ligand design can also prevent interpenetration by larger steric hindrances through introducing substituent groups, and a more meticulous route is the utilization of thermal/photo labile groups which can be eliminated by postactivation to preserve the larger free voids. However, the strategy to control over interpenetration by changing the shape of aperture has been scarcely realized until now.

elements.content: In contrast to the metal-carboxylate clusters that are widely employed as isotropic secondary building blocks (SBUs), some metal-carboxylate clusters augmented with pyridyl-like monodentate groups have been considered as anisotropic SBUs for constructing highly connected frameworks or pillared-layer structures. As shown in Scheme , the bimetallic clusters of M2(RCOO)4L4 (M = CoII, ZnII, CdII, etc.), joined by two bridging or chelating/bridging carboxylates with two chelating carboxylates and four monodentate pyridyl-like groups, have been recognized as the specific SBUs for constructing doubly pillared-layer (DPL) structures employing the combinations of dicarboxylates (as layer ligands) and 4,4′-bipyridine-like ligands (as pillared ligands). Recently, the structural evolution from metal/ligand components, to two-dimensional (2D) grid layers, to intermediate doubly pillared bilayers and ultimately to a three-dimensional (3D) DPL framework has been carefully observed and this supports the layer-by-layer hypothetical pillared-layer assembling principle. In that case, the 3D porous framework is noninterpenetration when the shortest pillared ligands of pyrazine were employed. Herein, we report the construction of DPL frameworks by combining H2bdc (1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid) or H2abdc (2-amino-1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid) with a lengthened pillared ligand, 4,4′-bipyridine (bpy), yielding a 2-fold interpenetrating structure of [Co2(bdc)2(bpy)2] (1) and a noninterpenetrating structure of [Co2(abdc)2(bpy)·8DMF] (2). The significant change from a nonporous framework to a porous framework represents the shape alteration of layer apertures and the pillared ligands reorientating around the pore, and presenting an effective strategy to control over the interpenetration for the doubly pillared-layer prototype with lengthened pillared ligands by using the amino substituent benzene dicarboxylate, which induces the coordinated modes of carboxylates and fixes the benzene ring to the layer plane by intramolecular hydrogen bonds.
elements.clean_text: In contrast to the metal-carboxylate clusters that are widely employed as isotropic secondary building blocks (SBUs), some metal-carboxylate clusters augmented with pyridyl-like monodentate groups have been considered as anisotropic SBUs for constructing highly connected frameworks or pillared-layer structures. As shown in Scheme , the bimetallic clusters of M2(RCOO)4L4 (M = CoII, ZnII, CdII, etc.), joined by two bridging or chelating/bridging carboxylates with two chelating carboxylates and four monodentate pyridyl-like groups, have been recognized as the specific SBUs for constructing doubly pillared-layer (DPL) structures employing the combinations of dicarboxylates (as layer ligands) and 4,4'-bipyridine-like ligands (as pillared ligands). Recently, the structural evolution from metal/ligand components, to two-dimensional (2D) grid layers, to intermediate doubly pillared bilayers and ultimately to a three-dimensional (3D) DPL framework has been carefully observed and this supports the layer-by-layer hypothetical pillared-layer assembling principle. In that case, the 3D porous framework is noninterpenetration when the shortest pillared ligands of pyrazine were employed. Herein, we report the construction of DPL frameworks by combining H2bdc (1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid) or H2abdc (2-amino-1,4-benzene dicarboxylic acid) with a lengthened pillared ligand, 4,4'-bipyridine (bpy), yielding a 2-fold interpenetrating structure of [Co2(bdc)2(bpy)2] (1) and a noninterpenetrating structure of [Co2(abdc)2(bpy)⋅8DMF] (2). The significant change from a nonporous framework to a porous framework represents the shape alteration of layer apertures and the pillared ligands reorientating around the pore, and presenting an effective strategy to control over the interpenetration for the doubly pillared-layer prototype with lengthened pillared ligands by using the amino substituent benzene dicarboxylate, which induces the coordinated modes of carboxylates and fixes the benzene ring to the layer plane by intramolecular hydrogen bonds.

elements.content:
Specific Bimetallic Clusters for Constructing Doubly-Pillared-Layers (DPL) Typical Structures<xref rid="s1fn1"></xref>

Harris notation is used to describe the varied binding modes of carboxylate as [X·Y 1 Y 2···Y n ], where X = total number of metals bound by carboxylate, Y = respective number of metals attached to each O donor atom.

elements.content: All chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (EA) were carried out on a Vario EL elemental analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a NETZSCH TG 209 F3 thermogravimetric analyzer under flowing N2 at a heating rate of 10 °C·min–1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Bruker D8-Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The nitrogen and methanol sorption isotherms were measured on an automatic volumetric BELSORP-max adsorption apparatus at 77 K (BEL Inc., Japan) or an IGA-003 multicomponent gravimetric analyzer (Hiden Isochema Ltd., U.K.) at 298 K, respectively.
elements.clean_text:
Experimental Section

General Considerations

All chemicals were commercially available and used without further purification. Elemental analyses (EA) were carried out on a Vario EL elemental analyzer. Fourier transform infrared (FT-IR) spectra were recorded on a Bruker Tensor 27 spectrometer using KBr pellets. Thermogravimetric analyses (TGA) were performed on a NETZSCH TG 209 F3 thermogravimetric analyzer under flowing N2 at a heating rate of 10 °C⋅min-1. Powder X-ray diffraction (PXRD) data were collected on a Bruker D8-Advance diffractometer with Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.5418 Å). The nitrogen and methanol sorption isotherms were measured on an automatic volumetric BELSORP-max adsorption apparatus at 77 K (BEL Inc., Japan) or an IGA-003 multicomponent gravimetric analyzer (Hiden Isochema Ltd., U.K.) at 298 K, respectively.

elements.content: Co(NO3)2·6H2O (87 mg, 0.3 mmol), H2bdc (49.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) and 4,4′-bipyridine (46.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF), and stirred in air for 30 min. The resulting mixture was then sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined reactor, and heated to 160 °C and kept for 80 h. After cooling down to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C·h–1, block red crystals were obtained (yield ca. 55%). EA (%) Calcd for C36H24Co2N4O8: C 57.01, H 3.19, N 7.39; found C 57.45, H 3.10, N, 7.13. FT-IR (cm–1, KBr): 3059w, 1607s, 1554s, 1519 m, 1424vs, 1396s, 1221w, 1159w, 1073w, 1017 m, 842 m, 816 m, 745 m, 631w, 512 m, 466w.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Co2(bdc)2(bpy)2] (1)

Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (87 mg, 0.3 mmol), H2bdc (49.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) and 4,4'-bipyridine (46.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF), and stirred in air for 30 min. The resulting mixture was then sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined reactor, and heated to 160 °C and kept for 80 h. After cooling down to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C⋅h-1, block red crystals were obtained (yield ca. 55%). EA (%) Calcd for C36H24Co2N4O8: C 57.01, H 3.19, N 7.39; found C 57.45, H 3.10, N, 7.13. FT-IR (cm-1, KBr): 3059w, 1607s, 1554s, 1519 m, 1424vs, 1396s, 1221w, 1159w, 1073w, 1017 m, 842 m, 816 m, 745 m, 631w, 512 m, 466w.

elements.content: The synthetic procedure was identical to that for 1, but the H2bdc was replaced by H2abdc (54.3 mg, 0.3 mmol). Prism-shaped purple crystals were then obtained (yield ca. 70%). EA (%) Calcd for C60H82Co2N14O16: C 52.48, H 6.02, N 14.28; found C 50.33, H 5.19, N 12.59. FT-IR (cm–1, KBr): 3440 m, 1663s, 1619s, 1535 m, 1379s, 1251w, 1106w, 1050w, 833w, 783 m, 666w, 511w, 449w.
elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Co2(abdc)2(bpy)2]⋅8DMF (2)

The synthetic procedure was identical to that for 1, but the H2bdc was replaced by H2abdc (54.3 mg, 0.3 mmol). Prism-shaped purple crystals were then obtained (yield ca. 70%). EA (%) Calcd for C60H82Co2N14O16: C 52.48, H 6.02, N 14.28; found C 50.33, H 5.19, N 12.59. FT-IR (cm-1, KBr): 3440 m, 1663s, 1619s, 1535 m, 1379s, 1251w, 1106w, 1050w, 833w, 783 m, 666w, 511w, 449w.

elements.content: Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on an Oxford Gemini S Ultra CCD diffractometer with mirror-monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) at 150(2) K. The crystal structure of 2 was solved by direct methods and difference Fourier syntheses using the SHELXTL software package. All non-hydrogen atoms of the frameworks were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically and refined using a riding model. As the highly disordered solvent molecules could not be modeled, the PLATON/SQUEEZE procedure was used to remove the contribution of reflection by DMF molecules. The chemical formula of 2 was estimated from the result of the SQUEEZE procedure combined with the result of TGA. Detailed crystallographic data and structure determination parameters are given in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles are provided in Table S1. The crystal data of 2 has been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center under deposition reference numbers CCDC No. 863438. The crystal structure of 1 is identical to a previously reported coordination polymer under a different synthesized condition,which was confirmed by indexing the cell parameters.
elements.clean_text:
X-ray Single-Crystal Structure Analysis

Single-crystal X-ray diffraction data were collected on an Oxford Gemini S Ultra CCD diffractometer with mirror-monochromated Cu Kα radiation (λ = 1.54184 Å) at 150(2) K. The crystal structure of 2 was solved by direct methods and difference Fourier syntheses using the SHELXTL software package. All non-hydrogen atoms of the frameworks were refined anisotropically, and hydrogen atoms were generated geometrically and refined using a riding model. As the highly disordered solvent molecules could not be modeled, the PLATON/SQUEEZE procedure was used to remove the contribution of reflection by DMF molecules. The chemical formula of 2 was estimated from the result of the SQUEEZE procedure combined with the result of TGA. Detailed crystallographic data and structure determination parameters are given in Table , and the selected bond lengths and angles are provided in  Table S1. The crystal data of 2 has been deposited in the Cambridge Crystallographic Data Center under deposition reference numbers CCDC No. 863438. The crystal structure of 1 is identical to a previously reported coordination polymer under a different synthesized condition,which was confirmed by indexing the cell parameters.

elements.content:
Crystallographic Data for <bold>2</bold> formula C60H82Co2N14O16 fw 1372.1 T (K) 150(2) cryst size (mm3) 0.12 × 0.08 × 0.05 cryst syst monoclinic space group P21 /c a (Å) 11.3737(4) b (Å) 17.9058(8) c (Å) 17.6013(7) β (deg) 99.234(4) V (Å3) 3538.1(2) Z 4 D c (g·cm–3) 0.74 F(000) 804 R 1 (I > 2σ) 0.1193 R 2 (all data) 0.3438 GOF on F 2 1.07 Δρmin/max (e/Å3) 1.89/–0.50

R 1 = ∑||F o| – |F c||/∑|F o|.

R 2 = [∑w(F o 2 – F c 2)2/∑w(F o 2)2]1/2.

As shown in Figure a, crystal structure 1 is comprised of the bimetallic cluster Co2(RCOO)4L4 as SBU, which is two CoII atoms joined by two bridging carboxylates and two chelating carboxylates from two independent bdc ligands in the equatorial plane, and braced by four pyridyl rings from four bpy ligands vertically to the equatorial plane. There are two kinds of bdc ligands (the bis-bidentate bridging modes and the bis-bidentate chelating modes), which interconnect the bimetallic clusters into a grid layer. As shown in Figure b, the dimensions of the grid for the bis-bidentate chelating bdc side are 14.89 Å, and that for the bis-bidentate side are 10.38 Å, respectively, enclosing the layer aperture in rectangle shape with the size of 8.87 × 6.84 Å2, which fits well for a pair of bpy (7.28 × 6.18 Å2). Pillared by pairs of bpy, the doubly pillared layer 3D frameworks could be relatively porous, and it could possess boxlike cage with pore volume of 8.39 × 7.49 × 4.27 Å3 (van der Waals radius of the framework excluded). However, the 2-fold interpenetration (Figure d) robs the framework of all the porosity and ultimately forms a non-porous structure.
elements.clean_text:
Results and Discussion

Crystal Structures

As shown in Figure a, crystal structure 1 is comprised of the bimetallic cluster Co2(RCOO)4L4 as SBU, which is two CoII atoms joined by two bridging carboxylates and two chelating carboxylates from two independent bdc ligands in the equatorial plane, and braced by four pyridyl rings from four bpy ligands vertically to the equatorial plane. There are two kinds of bdc ligands (the bis-bidentate bridging modes and the bis-bidentate chelating modes), which interconnect the bimetallic clusters into a grid layer. As shown in Figure b, the dimensions of the grid for the bis-bidentate chelating bdc side are 14.89 Å, and that for the bis-bidentate side are 10.38 Å, respectively, enclosing the layer aperture in rectangle shape with the size of 8.87 × 6.84 Å2, which fits well for a pair of bpy (7.28 × 6.18 Å2). Pillared by pairs of bpy, the doubly pillared layer 3D frameworks could be relatively porous, and it could possess boxlike cage with pore volume of 8.39 × 7.49 × 4.27 Å3 (van der Waals radius of the framework excluded). However, the 2-fold interpenetration (Figure d) robs the framework of all the porosity and ultimately forms a non-porous structure.

elements.content: Crystal structure of 1. (a) The bimetallic cluster SBU with two kinds of coordination modes of the bdc ligands. (b) The grid layer with a rectangle aperture fits the passage of a pair of bpy; (c) The boxlike cage enclosed by bdc and bpy; (d) a 2-fold interpenetrating framework leading to a non-porous structure.
elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of 1. (a) The bimetallic cluster SBU with two kinds of coordination modes of the bdc ligands. (b) The grid layer with a rectangle aperture fits the passage of a pair of bpy; (c) The boxlike cage enclosed by bdc and bpy; (d) a 2-fold interpenetrating framework leading to a non-porous structure.

elements.content: As shown in Figure a, crystal structure 2 possesses the identical bimetallic clusters Co2(RCOO)4L4 as SBUs similar to that of 1. The abdc in this structure represents only one kind of coordination mode: one segment with a bidentate bridging carboxylate, while another segment with a bidentate chelating carboxylate. It is easy to identify that the carboxylate adjacent to the amino adopts a bridging mode, which could be induced by the intramolecular hydrogen bond of N–H···O (the distance of N···O is 2.57(3) Å and ∠N–H···O is 124°). With the side dimension of 13.07 Å of the uniform coordination mode of abdc, the bimetallic clusters are interconnected into grid layer with a square aperture in the size of 6.57 × 6.47 Å2, which is smaller than a pair of bpy (7.28 × 6.18 Å2). Additionally, all the benzene rings of abdc are fixed upon the equatorial plane, owing to the hydrogen bond deriving from amino, which also diminishes the void of the layer. In comparison, the benzene ring of the bis-bidentate chelating bdc can rotate off the layer plane, which can be observed in 1 and other cases as another factor resulting in interpenetration. Without the interpenetration, the doubly pillared-layer structure of 2 is really porous with 63.3% void of the total crystal volume, possessing boxlike cages with the size of 8.39 × 6.30 × 6.01 Å3 (shown in Figure c and d), which are interconnected by layer apertures and channels between pillared ligands (Figure e and f, the distance between neighboring bpy are 6.30 or 6.01 Å, respectively) into a 3D pore system.
elements.clean_text: As shown in Figure a, crystal structure 2 possesses the identical bimetallic clusters Co2(RCOO)4L4 as SBUs similar to that of 1. The abdc in this structure represents only one kind of coordination mode: one segment with a bidentate bridging carboxylate, while another segment with a bidentate chelating carboxylate. It is easy to identify that the carboxylate adjacent to the amino adopts a bridging mode, which could be induced by the intramolecular hydrogen bond of N-H⋅⋅⋅O (the distance of N⋅⋅⋅O is 2.57(3) Å and ∠N-H⋅⋅⋅O is 124°). With the side dimension of 13.07 Å of the uniform coordination mode of abdc, the bimetallic clusters are interconnected into grid layer with a square aperture in the size of 6.57 × 6.47 Å2, which is smaller than a pair of bpy (7.28 × 6.18 Å2). Additionally, all the benzene rings of abdc are fixed upon the equatorial plane, owing to the hydrogen bond deriving from amino, which also diminishes the void of the layer. In comparison, the benzene ring of the bis-bidentate chelating bdc can rotate off the layer plane, which can be observed in 1 and other cases as another factor resulting in interpenetration. Without the interpenetration, the doubly pillared-layer structure of 2 is really porous with 63.3% void of the total crystal volume, possessing boxlike cages with the size of 8.39 × 6.30 × 6.01 Å3 (shown in Figure c and d), which are interconnected by layer apertures and channels between pillared ligands (Figure e and f, the distance between neighboring bpy are 6.30 or 6.01 Å, respectively) into a 3D pore system.

elements.content: Crystal structure of 2. (a) The bimetallic cluster with uniform coordination mode of the abdc ligand. (b) The grid layer with a square aperture blocks the passage for a pair of bpy; (c) The boxlike cage enclosed by abdc and bpy along the (011) plane; (d) The boxlike cage enclosed by abdc and bpy along the (01̅1) plane; (e) the perspective channel along the (011) plane; (f) the perspective channel along the (01̅1) plane.
elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of 2. (a) The bimetallic cluster with uniform coordination mode of the abdc ligand. (b) The grid layer with a square aperture blocks the passage for a pair of bpy; (c) The boxlike cage enclosed by abdc and bpy along the (011) plane; (d) The boxlike cage enclosed by abdc and bpy along the (01̅1) plane; (e) the perspective channel along the (011) plane; (f) the perspective channel along the (01̅1) plane.

elements.content: Detail analysis of the underlying networks for the two structures reveals that 2 is a topological isomer of 1, which can demonstrate a new doubly pillared-layer prototype with structural diversity induced by the different coordination mode of dicarboxylate. Considering the CoII as 5-connected node and the bridging carboxylate as 3-connected node, the topology of 1 can be described as a Schläfli short model (4·82)(43·65·82) or the vertex symbol 4·85·85, 4·4·4·62·62·62·62·8·8 (Figure a and b), while the topology of 2 with a Schläfli short symbol (4·62)(4·66·83) and vertex symbol 4·62·62, 4·63·63·63·63·62·62·8·8 (Figure d and e). As shown in Figure c and f, the pillar ligands are therefore reorientated by the topology, which changes the environment in the pores: the pairs of bpy in 1 are in a mutually parallel array, facing the dummy channel with the 6-ring plane; while the pairs of bpy in 2 are perpendicular to each one, which exposes both the 6-ring plane and the side hydrogen to the pore. Conceivably, introducing a substituent group on bpy might be more effective for modulating the pore surface or adjusting the channel apertures in 2 rather than in 1.
elements.clean_text: Detail analysis of the underlying networks for the two structures reveals that 2 is a topological isomer of 1, which can demonstrate a new doubly pillared-layer prototype with structural diversity induced by the different coordination mode of dicarboxylate. Considering the CoII as 5-connected node and the bridging carboxylate as 3-connected node, the topology of 1 can be described as a Schläfli short model (4⋅82)(43⋅65⋅82) or the vertex symbol 4⋅85⋅85, 4⋅4⋅4⋅62⋅62⋅62⋅62⋅8⋅8 (Figure a and b), while the topology of 2 with a Schläfli short symbol (4⋅62)(4⋅66⋅83) and vertex symbol 4⋅62⋅62, 4⋅63⋅63⋅63⋅63⋅62⋅62⋅8⋅8 (Figure d and e). As shown in Figure c and f, the pillar ligands are therefore reorientated by the topology, which changes the environment in the pores: the pairs of bpy in 1 are in a mutually parallel array, facing the dummy channel with the 6-ring plane; while the pairs of bpy in 2 are perpendicular to each one, which exposes both the 6-ring plane and the side hydrogen to the pore. Conceivably, introducing a substituent group on bpy might be more effective for modulating the pore surface or adjusting the channel apertures in 2 rather than in 1.

elements.content: Topological comparison between 1 and 2. (a) The coordination modes of bdc and simplification into the grid layer in 1. (b) The (4·82)(43·65·82) network in 1. (c) The parallel array of bpy and dummy channels in 1. (d) The coordination mode of abdc and the simplification into the grid layer in 2. (e) The (4·62)(4·66·83) networks in 2. (f) The bpy perpendicular to each other and the resulting cage-channel in 2.
elements.clean_text: 3  Topological comparison between 1 and 2. (a) The coordination modes of bdc and simplification into the grid layer in 1. (b) The (4⋅82)(43⋅65⋅82) network in 1. (c) The parallel array of bpy and dummy channels in 1. (d) The coordination mode of abdc and the simplification into the grid layer in 2. (e) The (4⋅62)(4⋅66⋅83) networks in 2. (f) The bpy perpendicular to each other and the resulting cage-channel in 2.

elements.content: Different from the diluting strategy to control over interpenetration, the noninterpenetrating structure of 2 can be readily synthesized in high yield. The phase purity of the as-synthesized sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (as shown in Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Figure S3) of the as-synthesized sample showed a sharp weight loss of 41.2% between 30 and 150 °C, corresponding to the removal of eight lattice DMF molecules (calcd 42.59%); no obvious weight loss during 150–250 °C, which indicated the framework survival after evacuating the guest molecules. Similar to other pillared-layered structures, the framework of 2 was observed with slight weight loss starting from 250 °C, which might be ascribed to the stripping of neutral pillared ligand bpy; and a sharp weight loss occurred starting from 350 °C indicating the collapse of whole frameworks.
elements.clean_text:
Bulk Phase Purity and Thermal Stability

Different from the diluting strategy to control over interpenetration, the noninterpenetrating structure of 2 can be readily synthesized in high yield. The phase purity of the as-synthesized sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (as shown in  Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA,  Figure S3) of the as-synthesized sample showed a sharp weight loss of 41.2% between 30 and 150 °C, corresponding to the removal of eight lattice DMF molecules (calcd 42.59%); no obvious weight loss during 150-250 °C, which indicated the framework survival after evacuating the guest molecules. Similar to other pillared-layered structures, the framework of 2 was observed with slight weight loss starting from 250 °C, which might be ascribed to the stripping of neutral pillared ligand bpy; and a sharp weight loss occurred starting from 350 °C indicating the collapse of whole frameworks.

elements.content: To achieve a mildly activated condition, the solvent-exchange procedure was conducted on as-synthesized 2 to remove the high-boiling point solvent of DMF. After the continuous exchange with ethanol for two days and ether for another two days, the sample of 2 was activated under high vacuum at room temperature overnight. As shown in Figure a, the N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K represents the reversible type I curve typical for microporous materials. Applying the Langmuir and Dubinin-Raduskhvich (DR) equations, the surface area and pore volume are estimated as 780 m2·g–1 and 0.44 cm3·g–1, respectively. As shown in Figure b, the methanol adsorption isotherm at 298 K indicates a hysteresis adsorption behavior, with a stronger interaction between the adsorbate and adsorbent, which might be attributed the substituent amino group. The adsorption amount of methanol at 0.89 atm is 197 mg/g, corresponding to 4.84 methanol molecules to per Co2 unit, which can also confirm the porosity.
elements.clean_text:
Adsorption Properties

To achieve a mildly activated condition, the solvent-exchange procedure was conducted on as-synthesized 2 to remove the high-boiling point solvent of DMF. After the continuous exchange with ethanol for two days and ether for another two days, the sample of 2 was activated under high vacuum at room temperature overnight. As shown in Figure a, the N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K represents the reversible type I curve typical for microporous materials. Applying the Langmuir and Dubinin-Raduskhvich (DR) equations, the surface area and pore volume are estimated as 780 m2⋅g-1 and 0.44 cm3⋅g-1, respectively. As shown in Figure b, the methanol adsorption isotherm at 298 K indicates a hysteresis adsorption behavior, with a stronger interaction between the adsorbate and adsorbent, which might be attributed the substituent amino group. The adsorption amount of methanol at 0.89 atm is 197 mg/g, corresponding to 4.84 methanol molecules to per Co2 unit, which can also confirm the porosity.

elements.content: N2 (at 77 K, top) and MeOH (at 298 K, bottom) sorption isotherms of 2.
elements.clean_text: 4  N2 (at 77 K, top) and MeOH (at 298 K, bottom) sorption isotherms of 2.

elements.content: In conclusion, a porous doubly pillared-layer structure has been constructed from the bimetallic cluster Co2(RCOO)4L4 extended by the combination of dicarboxylate and 4,4′-pyridine, which control over the interpenetration with the substituent effect of the amino group. That is, the intramolecular hydrogen bond between the amino group and the adjacent carboxylate, which induces the coordination mode of the carboxylates and fixes the coplanarity of the benzene ring, can ultimately change the shape and size of the layer aperture to prevent interpenetration. The result implies the noninterpenetrating DPL framework could serve as a prototype with anisotropically adjustable pore dimensions or functionalities by modifying the pillared ligands, which are of great undergoing interests in CO2 capture or separation of alkane mixtures.
elements.clean_text:
Conclusion

In conclusion, a porous doubly pillared-layer structure has been constructed from the bimetallic cluster Co2(RCOO)4L4 extended by the combination of dicarboxylate and 4,4'-pyridine, which control over the interpenetration with the substituent effect of the amino group. That is, the intramolecular hydrogen bond between the amino group and the adjacent carboxylate, which induces the coordination mode of the carboxylates and fixes the coplanarity of the benzene ring, can ultimately change the shape and size of the layer aperture to prevent interpenetration. The result implies the noninterpenetrating DPL framework could serve as a prototype with anisotropically adjustable pore dimensions or functionalities by modifying the pillared ligands, which are of great undergoing interests in CO2 capture or separation of alkane mixtures.

cln_elements.content:
Co(NO3)2·6H2O (87 mg, 0.3 mmol), H2bdc (49.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) and 4,4′-bipyridine (46.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL N,N′-dimethylformamide (DMF), and stirred in air for 30 min. The resulting mixture was then sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined reactor, and heated to 160 °C and kept for 80 h. After cooling down to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C·h–1, block red crystals were obtained (yield ca. 55%). EA (%) Calcd for C36H24Co2N4O8: C 57.01, H 3.19, N 7.39; found C 57.45, H 3.10, N, 7.13. FT-IR (cm–1, KBr): 3059w, 1607s, 1554s, 1519 m, 1424vs, 1396s, 1221w, 1159w, 1073w, 1017 m, 842 m, 816 m, 745 m, 631w, 512 m, 466w.

Synthesis of [Co<sub>2</sub>(abdc)<sub>2</sub>(bpy)<sub>2</sub>]·8DMF (<bold>2</bold>)

The synthetic procedure was identical to that for 1, but the H2bdc was replaced by H2abdc (54.3 mg, 0.3 mmol). Prism-shaped purple crystals were then obtained (yield ca. 70%). EA (%) Calcd for C60H82Co2N14O16: C 52.48, H 6.02, N 14.28; found C 50.33, H 5.19, N 12.59. FT-IR (cm–1, KBr): 3440 m, 1663s, 1619s, 1535 m, 1379s, 1251w, 1106w, 1050w, 833w, 783 m, 666w, 511w, 449w.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Synthesis of [Co2(bdc)2(bpy)2] (1)

Co(NO3)2⋅6H2O (87 mg, 0.3 mmol), H2bdc (49.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) and 4,4'-bipyridine (46.8 mg, 0.3 mmol) were dissolved in 10 mL N,N'-dimethylformamide (DMF), and stirred in air for 30 min. The resulting mixture was then sealed in a 20 mL Teflon-lined reactor, and heated to 160 °C and kept for 80 h. After cooling down to room temperature at a rate of 10 °C⋅h-1, block red crystals were obtained (yield ca. 55%). EA (%) Calcd for C36H24Co2N4O8: C 57.01, H 3.19, N 7.39; found C 57.45, H 3.10, N, 7.13. FT-IR (cm-1, KBr): 3059w, 1607s, 1554s, 1519 m, 1424vs, 1396s, 1221w, 1159w, 1073w, 1017 m, 842 m, 816 m, 745 m, 631w, 512 m, 466w.

Synthesis of [Co2(abdc)2(bpy)2]⋅8DMF (2)

The synthetic procedure was identical to that for 1, but the H2bdc was replaced by H2abdc (54.3 mg, 0.3 mmol). Prism-shaped purple crystals were then obtained (yield ca. 70%). EA (%) Calcd for C60H82Co2N14O16: C 52.48, H 6.02, N 14.28; found C 50.33, H 5.19, N 12.59. FT-IR (cm-1, KBr): 3440 m, 1663s, 1619s, 1535 m, 1379s, 1251w, 1106w, 1050w, 833w, 783 m, 666w, 511w, 449w.

cln_elements.content:
Different from the diluting strategy to control over interpenetration, the noninterpenetrating structure of 2 can be readily synthesized in high yield. The phase purity of the as-synthesized sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (as shown in Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA, Figure S3) of the as-synthesized sample showed a sharp weight loss of 41.2% between 30 and 150 °C, corresponding to the removal of eight lattice DMF molecules (calcd 42.59%); no obvious weight loss during 150–250 °C, which indicated the framework survival after evacuating the guest molecules. Similar to other pillared-layered structures, the framework of 2 was observed with slight weight loss starting from 250 °C, which might be ascribed to the stripping of neutral pillared ligand bpy; and a sharp weight loss occurred starting from 350 °C indicating the collapse of whole frameworks.

Adsorption Properties

To achieve a mildly activated condition, the solvent-exchange procedure was conducted on as-synthesized 2 to remove the high-boiling point solvent of DMF. After the continuous exchange with ethanol for two days and ether for another two days, the sample of 2 was activated under high vacuum at room temperature overnight. As shown in Figure a, the N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K represents the reversible type I curve typical for microporous materials. Applying the Langmuir and Dubinin-Raduskhvich (DR) equations, the surface area and pore volume are estimated as 780 m2·g–1 and 0.44 cm3·g–1, respectively. As shown in Figure b, the methanol adsorption isotherm at 298 K indicates a hysteresis adsorption behavior, with a stronger interaction between the adsorbate and adsorbent, which might be attributed the substituent amino group. The adsorption amount of methanol at 0.89 atm is 197 mg/g, corresponding to 4.84 methanol molecules to per Co2 unit, which can also confirm the porosity.
cln_elements.clean_text:
Bulk Phase Purity and Thermal Stability

Different from the diluting strategy to control over interpenetration, the noninterpenetrating structure of 2 can be readily synthesized in high yield. The phase purity of the as-synthesized sample was confirmed by powder X-ray diffraction (as shown in  Figure S2). Thermogravimetric analysis (TGA,  Figure S3) of the as-synthesized sample showed a sharp weight loss of 41.2% between 30 and 150 °C, corresponding to the removal of eight lattice DMF molecules (calcd 42.59%); no obvious weight loss during 150-250 °C, which indicated the framework survival after evacuating the guest molecules. Similar to other pillared-layered structures, the framework of 2 was observed with slight weight loss starting from 250 °C, which might be ascribed to the stripping of neutral pillared ligand bpy; and a sharp weight loss occurred starting from 350 °C indicating the collapse of whole frameworks.

Adsorption Properties

To achieve a mildly activated condition, the solvent-exchange procedure was conducted on as-synthesized 2 to remove the high-boiling point solvent of DMF. After the continuous exchange with ethanol for two days and ether for another two days, the sample of 2 was activated under high vacuum at room temperature overnight. As shown in Figure a, the N2 adsorption isotherm at 77 K represents the reversible type I curve typical for microporous materials. Applying the Langmuir and Dubinin-Raduskhvich (DR) equations, the surface area and pore volume are estimated as 780 m2⋅g-1 and 0.44 cm3⋅g-1, respectively. As shown in Figure b, the methanol adsorption isotherm at 298 K indicates a hysteresis adsorption behavior, with a stronger interaction between the adsorbate and adsorbent, which might be attributed the substituent amino group. The adsorption amount of methanol at 0.89 atm is 197 mg/g, corresponding to 4.84 methanol molecules to per Co2 unit, which can also confirm the porosity.

cln_elements.content:
Specific Bimetallic Clusters for Constructing Doubly-Pillared-Layers (DPL) Typical Structures<xref rid="s1fn1"></xref>

Harris notation is used to describe the varied binding modes of carboxylate as [X·Y 1 Y 2···Y n ], where X = total number of metals bound by carboxylate, Y = respective number of metals attached to each O donor atom.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Specific Bimetallic Clusters for Constructing Doubly-Pillared-Layers (DPL) Typical Structures      a Harris notation is used to describe the varied binding modes of carboxylate as [X⋅Y 1 Y 2⋅⋅⋅Y  n ], where X = total number of metals bound by carboxylate, Y = respective number of metals attached to each O donor atom.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 1. (a) The bimetallic cluster SBU with two kinds of coordination modes of the bdc ligands. (b) The grid layer with a rectangle aperture fits the passage of a pair of bpy; (c) The boxlike cage enclosed by bdc and bpy; (d) a 2-fold interpenetrating framework leading to a non-porous structure.
cln_elements.clean_text: 1  Crystal structure of 1. (a) The bimetallic cluster SBU with two kinds of coordination modes of the bdc ligands. (b) The grid layer with a rectangle aperture fits the passage of a pair of bpy; (c) The boxlike cage enclosed by bdc and bpy; (d) a 2-fold interpenetrating framework leading to a non-porous structure.

cln_elements.content: Crystal structure of 2. (a) The bimetallic cluster with uniform coordination mode of the abdc ligand. (b) The grid layer with a square aperture blocks the passage for a pair of bpy; (c) The boxlike cage enclosed by abdc and bpy along the (011) plane; (d) The boxlike cage enclosed by abdc and bpy along the (01̅1) plane; (e) the perspective channel along the (011) plane; (f) the perspective channel along the (01̅1) plane.
cln_elements.clean_text: 2  Crystal structure of 2. (a) The bimetallic cluster with uniform coordination mode of the abdc ligand. (b) The grid layer with a square aperture blocks the passage for a pair of bpy; (c) The boxlike cage enclosed by abdc and bpy along the (011) plane; (d) The boxlike cage enclosed by abdc and bpy along the (01̅1) plane; (e) the perspective channel along the (011) plane; (f) the perspective channel along the (01̅1) plane.

cln_elements.content: Topological comparison between 1 and 2. (a) The coordination modes of bdc and simplification into the grid layer in 1. (b) The (4·82)(43·65·82) network in 1. (c) The parallel array of bpy and dummy channels in 1. (d) The coordination mode of abdc and the simplification into the grid layer in 2. (e) The (4·62)(4·66·83) networks in 2. (f) The bpy perpendicular to each other and the resulting cage-channel in 2.
cln_elements.clean_text: 3  Topological comparison between 1 and 2. (a) The coordination modes of bdc and simplification into the grid layer in 1. (b) The (4⋅82)(43⋅65⋅82) network in 1. (c) The parallel array of bpy and dummy channels in 1. (d) The coordination mode of abdc and the simplification into the grid layer in 2. (e) The (4⋅62)(4⋅66⋅83) networks in 2. (f) The bpy perpendicular to each other and the resulting cage-channel in 2.

metadata.title:
From Nonporous to Porous
Doubly-Pillared-Layer Framework:
Control over Interpenetration via Shape Alteration of Layer Apertures
